{{Infobox company | name = TickX | logo = TickX_Logo.svg | industry = Events | founded = September, 2015 | founders = Sam Coley and Steve Pearce | hq_location = [[Manchester]], [[United Kingdom]] | website = {{URL|tickx.co.uk}} }}
'''TickX''' is an events and tickets [[search engine]], comparing events in the [[United Kingdom]], [[Republic of Ireland]], [[Spain]] and The [[Netherlands]] .<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.iq-mag.net/2017/09/tickx-launches-spain/#.Wgq76Wi0NPZ|title=TickX launches in Spain {{!}} IQ Magazine|date=2017-09-14|work=IQ Magazine|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/economia/20171023/tickx-busca-y-compara-entradas-6378977|title=TickX busca y compara entradas|last=Barcelona|first=El Periódico /|date=2017-10-23|work=elperiodico|access-date=2017-11-14|language=ES}}</ref>
While studying at the [[University of Manchester]], co-founder Steve Pearce wanted to create a single destination for event goers to discover events. <ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/business/tickx-receives-backing-ministry-sound-10214728|title=TickX receives backing from Ministry of Sound|last=Begum|first=Shelina|date=2015-10-08|work=men|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref> Pearce pitched the idea to family friend and future co-founder Sam Coley, a software developer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13805154.Ministry_of_Sound_back_Scots_entrepreneur_s__go_compare__site_for_tickets/|title=Ministry of Sound back Scots entrepreneur's 'go compare' site for tickets|website=HeraldScotland|language=en|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref>
In 2015, TickX received backing from [[Ministry of Sound]]<ref name=":1" />, with Pearce and Coley earning nominations as one of [[Virgin Group|Virgin]]'s "Four young entrepreneurs to watch in 2016".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.virgin.com/entrepreneur/four-young-entrepreneurs-watch-2016|title=Four young entrepreneurs to watch in 2016|last=Ross|first=Eleanor|date=2015-11-22|website=Virgin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In the second half of 2017, TickX expanded to the Republic of Ireland and Spain.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/skyscanner-for-events-has-landed-in-ireland-no-more-frantic-websitehopping-for-gig-tickets-36011073.html|title=‘Skyscanner for events’ has landed in Ireland - no more frantic website-hopping for gig tickets - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en}}</ref>
In July, 2017, TickX unveiled the world's first event [[Chatbot]] via [[Facebook Messenger]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iq-mag.net/2017/05/tickx-unveils-facebook-messenger-chatbot/#.WgrLxGi0NPZ|title=TickX unveils world-first Messenger chatbot {{!}} IQ Magazine|date=2017-05-31|work=IQ Magazine|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-GB}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=September 2011}} {{italic title}} [[File:Whitaker's 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Front cover]]
'''''Whitaker's''''' is a [[almanac|reference book, published annually]] in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name ="American Political Science Review 1985"/><ref name ="The Burlington Magazine 1915"/> The book was originally published by J Whitaker & Sons from 1868 to 1997, then by [[The Stationery Office]] until 2003, and then by [[A & C Black]] which became a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Bloomsbury Publishing]] in 2011. The 150th edition of ''Whitaker's'' was published on 16 November 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bloomsbury.com/uk/whitakers-2018-9781472935021/|title=Whitaker's 2018|last=Bloomsbury.com|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==First publication== [[Joseph Whitaker (publisher)|Joseph Whitaker]] began preparing his Almanack in the autumn of 1868. He postponed publication of the first edition on learning of the resignation of [[Benjamin Disraeli]] on 1 December 1868, so that he could include details of the new [[First Gladstone Ministry|Gladstone administration]]. At the same time, Whitaker continued to expand the information so that the initially planned 329 pages grew to 370. The first edition of the Almanack appeared on 23 December 1868,<ref>"Whitaker's Almanack" (advertisement), ''The Times'', 21 December 1868, p. 14.</ref> priced at 1 [[Shilling (British coin)|shilling]], introduced by a short editorial piece written by Joseph Whitaker. It began "The Editor does not put forward this Almanack as perfect: yet he ventures to think that he has succeeded in preparing a work which will commend itself to those who desire to see improvement in this direction." It concluded by inviting critics to suggest ways in which improvements could be made.<ref>"Advertisement", "An Almanack For the Year of Our Lord 1869. By Joseph Whitaker.", J. Whitaker, 1868, p. 6.</ref> The ''[[The Guardian|Manchester Guardian]]'', reviewing the first edition, described it as "the largest of the cheap almanacks" to appear, and noted it contained a great deal more valuable information than other such works.<ref>"Almanacks", ''Manchester Guardian'', 27 December 1868, p. 3.</ref> In 2013, the 2014 edition became the first to be published under the new simpler branding of "''Whitaker's''".
==Content== ''Whitaker's Almanack'' consists of articles, lists and tables on a wide range of subjects including [[education]], the [[peerage]], [[government]] departments, health and social issues, and the [[Social environment|environment]].
The largest section is the countries directory, which includes recent [[history]], [[politics]], economic information and culture overviews. Each edition also features a selection of critical essays focusing on events of the previous year. Extensive [[Astronomy|astronomical]] data covering the forthcoming year is published at the rear of the book.
''Whitaker's Almanack'' is not an [[encyclopaedia]] but more of a [[yearbook]] of contemporary matters and a directory of various establishments in the [[UK]] (such as clubs, public bodies and [[universities]]).
Whitaker's was prized enough that [[Winston Churchill]] took a personal interest in the continued publication of the book after its [[headquarters]] were destroyed in [[The Blitz]]; a copy is also sealed in [[Cleopatra's Needle (London)|Cleopatra's Needle]] on the north bank of the [[River Thames]].
==Formats== Each year the ''Almanack'' is published in two formats – the Standard Edition and a shortened Concise Edition. In previous years, a larger-format of the Standard Edition, [[Bookbinding|bound]] in [[leather]], was produced for [[libraries]]. Both editions were redesigned in 1993 and 2004 to increase the page size and improve legibility.
==Editors== The ''Almanack'''s current Executive Editor is Ruth Northey, whilst former editor Hilary Marsden continues to contribute.
===Editors since 1868=== There have been nine editors since 1868:<ref>{{cite book |edition= Facsimile|title= Whitaker's Almanack 1900|url= |accessdate= |year= 1999|publisher= [[The Stationery Office]]|location= London|isbn= 0-11-702247-0|page=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |authorlink= |title= Whitaker's Almanack 2016|url= http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/whitakers-2016-9781472909305/|accessdate= |year= |publisher=[[A & C Black]] |location= London|isbn= 978-1-4729-0930-5|page=}}</ref> {{Div col|colwidth=21em}} * [[Joseph Whitaker (publisher)|Joseph Whitaker]] 1868–1895 * Sir [[Cuthbert Whitaker]] 1895–1950 * F. H. C. Tatham 1950–1981 * Richard Blake 1981–1986 * Hilary Marsden 1986–1999 * Lauren Simpson 1999–2004 * Inna Ward 2004–2008 * Claire Fogg 2008–2010 * Ruth Northey 2010– {{div col end}}
==Alternative publications== {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} *''[[The World Almanac and Book of Facts]]'' *''[[The World Factbook]]'' *''[[TIME Almanac with Information Please]]'' *''[[The New York Times Almanac]]'' *''[[Der Fischer Weltalmanach]]'' *''[[Europa World Year Book]]'' {{div col end}}
==In popular culture== *In the short story "[[Beasts and Super-Beasts|A Holiday Task]]" by [[Saki]], a [[Nobility|titled]] [[amnesiac]] looks through the list of peers in ''Whitaker's'' in an unsuccessful attempt to remember who she is. *''Whitaker's Almanack'' provides the key to a [[book cipher]] message at the beginning of [[Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s 1915 [[Sherlock Holmes]] novel ''[[The Valley of Fear]]''. *''Whitaker's Almanack'' is mentioned in chapter 2 of [[Bram Stoker]]'s ''[[Dracula]]'', with a copy being owned by the Count. It is also mentioned in [[Virginia Woolf]]'s short story "[[A Haunted House and Other Short Stories|The Mark on the Wall]]", the James Bond novel ''[[Moonraker (novel)|Moonraker]]''<ref name="trivia">http://whitakersalmanack.com/history/whitakers-trivia/</ref> and Evelyn Waugh's ''[[Vile Bodies]]''.<ref name="trivia"/> *In "The Round Dozen", a short story by [[W. Somerset Maugham]], a character recalls being advised by a famous novelist that the two most useful books for a writer are the Bible and ''Whitaker's Almanack''.<ref name="trivia"/>
==References== {{reflist|24em|refs=
<ref name ="American Political Science Review 1985">{{cite journal |first1= |last1= |first2= |last2= |authorlink1= |date=December 1985 |title=Reviewed Work(s): Whitaker's Almanack 1985: The Year Book by |journal=The [[American Political Science Review]] |volume=79 |issue=4 |pages=1281 |publisher=[[American Political Science Association]] |doi= |url= https://www.jstor.org/stable/1956423|accessdate= August 3, 2018 |quote= The 117th in its series, this volume provides considerable information on British government and society. The complete edition also includes several additional pages that cover such topics as the British Commonwealth of Nations, dependent territories, basic information on foreign countries, the United Nations, sports and the arts, the media, British architecture, science,education, trade unions, and more. Volume contains index.}}</ref>
<ref name ="The Burlington Magazine 1915">{{cite journal |first1= |last1= |first2= |last2= |authorlink1= |date=February 1915 |title=Reviewed Work(s): Whitaker's Almanack, 1915 by ; Who's Who, 1915 by |journal= [[The Burlington Magazine|The Burlington Magazine for Connoisseurs]] |volume= 26|issue=143 |pages=216-217 |publisher=Burlington Magazine Publications Ltd. |doi= |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/859969 |accessdate= August 3, 2018 |quote= We acknowledge with thanks the receipt of "Who's Who " and "Whitaker's Almanack ". Both these publications maintain their usual very high standard, though the war has naturally affected them considerably. In "Whitaker's Almanack" the space devoted last year to "The World's Peace" and " Proceedings of the Hague Tribunal " has this year been given up to an account of the origins of "The Great War", which we commend to our readers' attention. We note with approval the omission of the Emperor William's and the Crown Prince's name, with those of other belligerents, from the list of [[Order of the Garter|Knights of the Garter]]}}</ref>
}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.whitakersalmanack.com/}} *[http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/whitakers-2016-9781472909305/ Bloomsbury.com]

{{Infobox ancient site |name = Wulfsen horse burial |native_name = Pferdebestattung von Wulfsen {{de icon}} |alternate_name = |image = Pferdebestattung Wulfsen.jpg |alt = |caption = The horse grave of Wulfsen shown in situ |map_type = Germany |map_alt = |map_size = |relief = |coordinates = {{coord|53|18|23|N|10|09|30|E|display=inline,title}} |location = [[Wulfsen]], [[Lower Saxony]], Germany |region = [[Old Saxony]] |type = Grave |part_of = |length = {{convert|230|cm|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|240|cm|abbr=on}} |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = 700 to 800 AD |abandoned = |epochs = [[Early Middle Ages]] |cultures = [[Saxons|Saxon]] |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = 1974 |archaeologists = |condition = |ownership = |management = |public_access = |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |notes = }}
[[File:Pferdebestattung Wulfsen Vitrine.jpg|thumbnail|right|Presentation of the burial site model in the permanent collection. Shown in 2008.]]
The '''Wulfsen horse burial''' is an [[Early Middle Ages|early medieval]] [[horse burial]], consisting of three [[horse]]s, that was discovered in 1974 in a [[Saxons|Saxon]] [[grave field]] in the village of [[Wulfsen]], in the German district of [[Harburg, Hamburg|Harburg]]. The [[Feature (archaeology)|find]] was [[Rescue archaeology|rescued]] as a [[varnish profile]], which is on display in the permanent exhibition of the [[Archäologisches Museum Hamburg|Archaeological Museum Hamburg]] in [[Harburg, Hamburg]].<ref>Topic Death, Show case no. 116.</ref><ref name="Articus">{{cite book | last1 =Articus | first1 =Rüdiger | last2 =Brandt | first2 =Jochen | last3 =Först | first3 =Elke | last4 =Krause | first4 =Yvonne | last5 =Merkel | first5 =Michael | last6 =Mertens | first6 =Kathrin | last7 =Weiss | first7 =Rainer-Maria | title =Archaeological Museum Hamburg Helms-Museum: A short guide to the Tour of the Times | series = Archaeological Museum Hamburg publication | volume =103 | edition = | year =2013 | location = Hamburg | pages =158 | isbn =978-3-931429-24-9 }}</ref>
== Discovery == The [[archaeological site]] was located on the northeastern escarpment of a sand pit near Wulfsen. In summer of 1974 a [[fossil]] collector observed a discoloration of the soil, which he considered of archaeological interest. He reported his observation to the Museum of the Principality of Lüneburg, which forwarded the message to the Helms-Museum in Hamburg-Harburg being the archaeological authority for the region. An [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavation]] was conducted on the already disturbed burial site, which unearthed 35 human burials and the horse burial, containing the three horses. Due to the sandy soil, preservation of the burials was relatively poor. In total 26 older burials, oriented in north-south direction and nine younger burials oriented in east-west direction were excavated. Except for two [[arrowhead]]s in a young person's [[grave]], no other [[grave goods]] were observed.<ref name="Ahrens">{{cite journal | last = Ahrens | first = Claus | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Ein neues spätsächsisches Gräberfeld mit Dreifach-Pferdebestattung bei Wulfsen, Kreis Harburg | journal = Hammaburg N.F. | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 119–124 | publisher = | location = | year = 1975 | language = German | url = | jstor = | issn = 0173-0886 | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate = }}</ref>
== Horse burial == The three horses were buried in a steep-walled pit of {{Convert|230|cm|in}} by {{Convert|240|cm|in}}. The bodies of the animals were fully decomposed, only [[bone]]s and [[teeth]] remaining, but the bones were very brittle and fragile. Offerings or grave goods such as [[bridle]]s were not detected. All the horses were lying on their left side, orientated in south–north direction. Their heads were placed in an upright posture on an elevated part of the pit. The middle horse was lying with its [[abdomen]] in a [[ventral]] position. The [[leg]]s of the middle and eastern animal were sharply [[Flexion|flexed]]. The legs of the western horse were lying in a half-[[Extension (kinesiology)|extended]] position; it occupied about half of the pit's space. By use of a working platform, the bones were carefully exposed and soaked with cold [[glue]], the pit was then laminated with [[lacquer]] and [[crêpe paper]]. The single bones were further secured with wires and pins. Then the pit was filled with a construction [[foam]], secured in a wooden crate and recovered as a block. The entire object consists of a prepared sand layer of about {{Convert|3|mm|in}} to {{Convert|4|mm|in}} millimeters thickness with the embedded bone.<ref name="Ahrens"/> The poor preservation of the bones complicated [[Zoology|zoological]] investigations. The western horse was likely a [[mare]], the others [[stallion]]s. Their [[withers]] has been between {{Convert|130|cm|in}} and {{Convert|140|cm|in}}, which is relatively small compared to today's standards, but was average for those days. The ages of the animals have been determined between five and seven years.<ref name="Reichenstein">{{cite journal | last = Reichenstein | first = Hans | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Bemerkungen zu der Pferdebestattung von Wulfsen aus zoologisch-haustierkundlicher Sicht | journal = Hammaburg N.F. | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 125–126 | publisher = | location = | year = 1975 | language = German | url = | jstor = | issn = 0173-0886 | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate = }}</ref>
== Interpretation == [[Image:Lego Wulfsen horse burial.jpg|thumb|The excavation of the Wulfsen horse burial as a [[LEGO]] miniature]] Based on evidence such as mortuary practice, the geographical orientation of remains and their grave goods, the burial was dated to 700–800 AD.<ref name="Ahrens"/> The younger burials especially are dated to a period shortly before the wide [[Christianization]] of the region, which resulted in fundamental changes of burial practices. The [[horse burial]] could not be clearly assigned to one of the warrior's graves, therefore it is unclear whether was an individual burial of the animals or it was an addition to one of the human interments. Funerals of animals, especially of individual horses are well known from many grave fields of the Early Middle Ages.<ref name="Ahrens"/> Similar burial sites have been found in [[Suffolk]], England.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.angelcynnreenactmentsociety.org.uk/home/anglo-saxon-horseman-s-grave-in-suffolk| title = Anglo Saxon Horseman's Grave in Suffolk| work = Angelcynn Re-Enactment Society | accessdate = 2012-08-20}}</ref> Triple horse burials, for example, were discovered near [[Griefstedt]] ([[Sömmerda (district)]]) in [[Thuringia]] and [[Beckum, Germany|Beckum]] ([[Warendorf (district)]]) in [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], but for north-eastern Lower-Saxony it is unprecedented.<ref name="Ahrens"/>
A [[LEGO]] miniature of the excavation of Wulfsen horse burial was built in 2013 for the special exhibition ''LEGO Zeitreise'' (LEGO time travel) of Archäologische Museum Hamburg.

Harburg | publisher = Wachholtz | location = Neumünster | year = 2000 | language = German | isbn = 3-529-02010-9 }} *{{cite journal | last = Ahrens | first = Claus | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Ein neues spätsächsisches Gräberfeld mit Dreifach-Pferdebestattung bei Wulfsen, Kreis Harburg | journal = Hammaburg N.F. | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 119–124 | publisher = | location = | year = 1975 | language = German | url = | jstor = | issn = 0173-0886 | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate = }} *{{cite journal | last = Reichenstein | first = Hans | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Bemerkungen zu der Pferdebestattung von Wulfsen aus zoologisch-haustierkundlicher Sicht | journal = Hammaburg N.F. | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 125–126 | publisher = | location = | year = 1975 | language = German | url = | jstor = | issn = 0173-0886 | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate = }}
